However, Walter Sisulu, an ANC leader, said Sunday the government should not station the battalion of black Angolans in Natal. ``We are sure that their presence will aggravate the situation instead of bringing peace,'' said Sisulu, head of the ANC's internal wing. Most of the ANC leadership remains in exile. The South African Defense Force said the battalion was chosen because its members ``are neutral and do not have affiliations which could be seen to side with factions involved in the unrest in Natal.'' Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, but differ over tactics. The ANC has waged a guerrilla campaign, though it is largely dormant now. The organization favors sanctions, boycotts, strikes and other confrontational methods to pressure the white-led government. Inkatha does not endorse any of these measures and Buthelezi is a proponent of capitalism, in contrast to the socialist-leaning ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Chinatown Contingent Plans Protest Of Underground Freeway Plan
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Chinatown, normally jammed with tourists, has been suffering financially since October's earthquake smashed one of the main highways leading to the maze of crowded streets and bustling shops. So when Mayor Art Agnos suggested the crippled Embarcadero Freeway be destroyed instead of repaired, with a new road built at ground level or underground, merchants decided they had had enough. Activist Rose Pak of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce is leading the fight to rebuild the 1.7-mile freeway. At her urging, hundreds of Chinatown merchants planned to lock their doors Monday and show up at a Board of Supervisors meeting where the freeway's fate was expected to be decided. Agnos argues the freeway is ugly _ it blocks prime views of San Francisco Bay _ and too expensive to repair and reopen. His supporters on the issue include many groups who oppposed it even before it opened in 1959. They include preservationists and urban design activists, who say the freeway sacrifices city streets and alters the character of neighborhoods. The freeway survived a 1986 vote to spend $10 million to tear it down. But opponents of the mayor's plan say rebuilding the damaged highway would take far less time than building a new underground stretch, and time is the key to recovery of businesses in the nation's second-largest Chinatown. Pak called the plan to shut down the neighborhood's shops and cafes for a show of force as the supervisors vote on the Agnos proposal ``a very basic, grass roots, humble gesture.'' A longtime ally of Agnos, the outspoken Pak is steamed that the mayor has rejected the message of 10,000 people who signed pro-repair petitions. ``It's a political statement that we're not a silent minority,'' she said. Signs supporting the shutdown are posted in store windows throughout Chinatown. Under Agnos' proposal, $120 million would be spent to replace the elevated roadway with a sunken one leading into Chinatown, North Beach, Fisherman's Wharf and the rest of the waterfront. He acknowledges it could take five or six years to complete. It would cost far less, an estimated $32 million, to reinforce and patch up the freeway. The state Transportation Department has that amount set aside for the repair and is awaiting the city decision of whether work can begin. One supervisor the protesters have on their side at Monday's meeting will be Tom Hsieh, who says he's outraged by the mayor's decision. It was explained to the board of supervisors in a two-page release devoid of details such as where the $120 million would come from, and what Chinatown is supposed to do while the underground expressway is built, he said. ``Some leaders have no idea of the hardship and the trauma people in that community are facing,'' Hsieh said. ``They lost not just business, they lost employment.'' Residents and businessmen in Chinatown ``just went wild'' when they heard the mayor's plan, he said. ``They're simply panicked. They have no confidence in the city government that it can take care of their daily life.'' At the Golden Gate Restaurant Association, executive director Cecilia Metz said no vote of the organization's members has been taken on the freeway controversy, but the sentiment is clear. ``No one can wait five or six years,'' she said. Joining opposition to the freeway demolition has been the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce business panel, which voted last week to support rebuilding the damaged road. Harold Lee, executive director of Asian Inc., a non-profit small business advocacy group, said Agnos' plan will cost him not just in Chinatown, but with people who own businesses or work in nearby, less vocal areas as well. ``Of course it will hurt Agnos politically,'' he said. ``People are not stupid.'' But Agnos insists he's pursuing the best, long-term interests of the city rather than short-term needs of any one community. ``Nobody wants to sacrifice short-term discomfort for long-term progress, but that's what a great city has to do, or it will become stagnant,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Mass Grave Discovered
DOC.TEXT: A mass grave containing the remains of nearly 40 people who apparently disappeared during World War II has been discovered in southwestern Bulgaria, the official BTA news agency reported. The grave was found near the village of Dobrinishte, on the site of a hideout used by the anti-Nazi partisan Ivan Kozarev, BTA said in a dispatch late Saturday. ``Local people say the victims are probably some of the residents of the former Razlog district who went missing in October 1944,'' BTA said, without elaborating on the possible circumstances of their deaths.

In training for a marathon, Juma Ikangaa likes to stay just ahead of his running partners. ``Juma's what we call a `two-stepper,' '' said Greg Meyer, who trained for nearly a month with the Tanzanian at Alamosa, Colo., in preparation for the Boston Marathon. ``When training with Juma, he'll always be two steps ahead of you. Steve Jones is like that. Joan Benoit (Samuelson) is like that. If you're running with them, they have to get two steps ahead of you. It's just a habit, I guess.'' Not so much a habit for Ikangaa, but a good practice. ``Whenever I train, I always think about the race,'' he said. ``I think about the hills, I imagine I am running at Boston and I know I have to push very hard. ``Training in your mind is like running the Boston course.'' Monday, the imagining will stop for Ikangaa. The race, the oldest continuous marathon in the world, will be run for the 94th time. And Ikangaa, the second-place finisher in the past two Boston Marathons, goes in as the favorite against a star-studded field, including Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya, who beat him by one second _ a half-step _ in the 1988 race. Ikangaa has earned the favorite's role and the coveted No. 1 for Monday's race by being ranked No. 1 in the world for 1989 after winning the 1989 New York City Marathon in 2 hours, 8 minutes, 1 second, his career best. Hussein, who finished fourth in defense of his Boston title last year, is coming off a second-place finish at Honolulu in December and a fifth in the Commonwealth Games. He is seeking his first victory since Boston two years ago. The other top contenders also are foreigners, including Rob de Castella of Australia, the 1986 Boston winner in a course-record 2:07:51; Steve Jones of Wales, the '87 Boston runner-up and '88 New York City winner; Gelindo Bordin of Italy, the '88 Olympic gold medalist; Zeleke Metafaria of Ethiopia, the '89 World Cup champion; Simon Robert Naali of Tanzania, the '89 Honolulu champion and '90 Commonwealth Games third-place finisher; Salvador Garcia of Mexico, the '89 New Jersey Waterfront winner, and Geoff Smith of Britain, the 1984-85 Boston champion. The leading Americans are Meyer, from Grand Rapids, Mich., the '83 Boston winner, and Steve Spence of Hanover, Pa., the nation's leading road racer last year. The women's field also has the 1988 gold medalist, Rosa Mota of Portugal. Mota will be trying to become the first three-time winner since women officially began competing in the race in 1972. She won in 1987 and 1988. The other top women include Veronique Marot of Britain, ranked second in the world; Kim Jones of Spokane, Wash., ranked No. 3; Laura Fogli of Italy, the Olympic sixth-place finisher, and Zoya Ivanova of the Soviet Union, the '89 Los Angeles winner. There is a record field for the race, with a total of 9,362 entries.

DOC.HEAD: 150,000 People Take Part In Rally Marking Kim Il Sung's Birthday
DOC.TEXT: About 150,000 North Koreans rallied in North Korea's capital Sunday as groups countrywide celebrated the 78th birthday of President Kim Il Sung, official news reports said. At May Day Stadium in Pyongyang, Communist North Korea's capital, 150,000 people listened to speeches glorifying Kim by Vice President Li Jong Ok and other officials, the North's Korean Central News Agency reported. Kim and his son and heir apparent, Kim Jong Il, were not listed among those attending the rally. Some recent news reports from Beijing have quoted East European diplomats there as saying the aging Communist ruler may turn over some of his official posts to his son soon after his birthday. But there was no indication of such a shift in the official North Korean reports, monitored in Tokyo. Kim has led the secretive nation since its formation after the division of the Korean peninsula at the end of World War II, and he has created a huge personality cult. In a birthday editorial Sunday, the Communist Party newspaper Rodong Sinmun said that through Kim's guidance, ``our nation which was weak and backward in the past has been able to grow into a mighty and independent nation.'' South Korea's Yonhap news agency reported last week that North Korea had invited about 100 arts ensembles from 60 countries to celebrate Kim's birthday, designated a national holiday. Yonhap said North Korean citizens on Sunday would get a special ration of goods ordinarily in limited supply in the country, such as meat, cookies, wine and fruit.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Leaders Say U.S.-Soviet Trade Improvements Could Be Threatened
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders in both parties warned Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Sunday that carrying out his threatened economic blockade against Lithuania could derail opening trade relations between the United States and Moscow. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said retaliation by Moscow to Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence would jeopardize a trade agreement President Bush and Gorbachev hoped to sign at a summit in June. The Bush administration, meanwhile, was taking what Secretary of State James A. Baker III described as a ``wait and see'' attitude as the Kremlin-imposed deadline for Lithuania to rescind its declaration of independence passed Sunday night. Mitchell, who on Saturday condemned Gorbachev's ultimatum as ``precisely the wrong approach,'' said Sunday he was waiting for Bush to do the same. But, in an interview on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' he also supported the administration's reluctance to issue specific counter threats. ``We ought not to be announcing in advance what we're going to do when we don't know for sure that they are going to do,'' he said. ``He has made a threat. He has not yet carried it out. We don't know what they're going to do.'' However, Mitchell said ``a wide range'' of possible reactions could include canceling the summit, slowing down the trade negotiations and ``in between those ... a whole lot of things that can be done.'' Dole, interviewed on NBC's ``Meet the Press'' from Jerusalem, questioned the wisdom of canceling the summit if the Soviets carry out their threat to cut off supplies to Lithuania. ``On areas where we mutually benefit, arms control, maybe those should proceed on target,'' he said. ``It would probably be a little strained summit if, in fact, this continues. But I look at the arms control issues as being mutually beneficial to the United States and to the Soviet Union.'' Any U.S. retaliation, Dole said, should be limited to measures, such as a trade accord, that are more to Moscow's benefit than to the United States. Mitchell said he and five other senators just back from the Soviet Union after meeting with Gorbachev and two Lithuanian delegations last week planned to meet with Bush in the next few days to give him their impressions. ``I think there is room for movement on both sides ... some possibility of bridging the gap between them,'' Mitchell said.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Killed In Tank Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An explosion at a tank field killed an oil worker Sunday and sparked a fire that scorched gasoline tanks and sent thick black smoke billowing over the city until it was doused, authorities said. The 11:25 a.m. fire at the Port of Tampa was put out by noon by fireboats, helicopters, about 50 firefighters and 16 vehicles, said fire department spokesman Matt Ballaban. The fire scorched at least three tanks, each holding several thousand gallons, in the tank field, Ballaban said. The unidentified Citgo Petroleum Corp. worker was killed when a vapor recovery unit exploded. The unit recovers petroleum product vapors during loading operations for condensation back into liquid form, Ballaban said. No other injuries were reported. Citgo spokesman Kent Young in Tulsa, Okla., said the employee's name was being withheld pending notification of relatives. Young said terminal operations had been suspended and an investigation was begun into the cause of the explosion. Citgo's Tampa operation has capacity of 241,000 barrels of oil. It receives oil products by tanker, barge and pipeline; the products are stored there and loaded into trucks for shipment, Young said.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Communists Would Win Plurality In Free Vote, Poll Indicates
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communists would win if a free election were held now, but the main coalition of opposition parties is gaining support among voters, according to an opinion poll released Sunday. The results of the poll released by the semi-official Sofia Press Agency contrast with the outcome of multiparty elections that have transformed other Eastern European countries. The Communists lost overwhelmingly in elections in East Germany and Hungary this year and in Poland last year. While approving free elections and professing to accept full democracy, the Communists remain in full control in Bulgaria prior to the elections, scheduled for June 10. The Bulgarian poll, based on a survey of more than 3,100 voters completed Saturday, showed 40.7 percent of the respondents supporting the Socialist Party, the new name adopted by the Communist Party after long-time Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted last year. The opposition Union of Democratic Forces drew support from 29.7 percent of those polled. The Sofia Press Agency said 5.6 percent of the respondents were not likely to vote for any group. It did not account for the preferences of the missing 24 percent, but indicated about 10 percent of those polled supported the Bulgarian National Agrarian Union, another opposition group. The survey showed no erosion of support for the Socialists over the last month but a gain of 7 percent over the same period by the Union of Democratic Forces, the press agency reported without elaborating. No margin of error was given for the poll, conducted by the National Center for Studying Public Opinion in Bulgaria, and no details on the questions asked were published.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Bans Officials From Receiving Foreign Gifts
DOC.TEXT: The national assembly passed a decree banning government officials from accepting gifts from foreigners, a newspaper reported Sunday. The 250-member assembly approved the new legislation Saturday, said Al-Thawra, the official newspaper of the ruling Baath Party. The law orders government employees to hand over any gift from a foreign person or organization to the government within seven days after receiving it. The paper said employees who violate the new law could face imprisonment and a fine ranging from $1,600 to $22,400. The newspaper did not specify the prison sentences for violators. But a lawyer said the sentence would range from one day to five years in prison. Government employees who receive bribes from foreigners in return for providing specific services can be sentenced to death under Iraqi law.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Robles, Former Panamanian President, Dies at 84
DOC.TEXT: Marcos Aurelio Robles, a former president of Panama who oversaw the construction of a part of the Pan-American Highway, died in Miami, family members said Sunday. He was 84. Family members say Robles died Saturday after a long illness, but they did not specify the cause of death. Robles was elected president in 1964. He was succeeded in 1968 by Arnulfo Arias, the last elected president of Panama before a military coup Oct. 11 that year led by Gen. Omar Torrijos. Robles fled to Miami after the military overthrow. Robles was born Nov. 8, 1905, in the western town of Aguadulce. A member of the Liberal Party, served as a congressman, minister of justice, treasury minister and an executive with the National Bank of Panama. From 1928-30 Robles worked at the Panamanian Embassy in France. He created the Institute for Human Resources and oversaw the construction of part of the Pan-American Highway, which connects Panama to the United States. Family members said the body would be brought back to Panama for burial, according to his wishes.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Clash With Moslem Militants in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Indian security forces clashed repeatedly Sunday with Moslem militants in the capital of the northern Kashmir region and made dozens of arrests. The clashes come at a time of escalating tension over Kashmir between predominantly Hindu India and Pakistan, a Moslem nation. The two countries have accused each other of trying to provoke a war. The leader of a powerful, fundamentalist Hindu party warned Sunday that Moslem Pakistan would ``cease to exist'' if it began a war with India. L.K. Advani, head of the Bharatiya Janata Party, a key member of the governing left-right coalition, told a crowd in Bombay that Pakistani interference in Kashmir should be recognized as ``undeclared war by Pakistan,'' the United News of India news agency reported. Advani urged the central government to send ``a strong signal'' to Islamabad. Indian police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, reported no casualties in at least five clashes Sunday in the Kashmiri capital of Srinagar. Witnesses, however, reported that security forces shot and wounded a 12-year-old girl on a small ferry on Lake Dul, outside Srinagar. The girl was hospitalized in serious condition, they said. Witnesses said the boat was apparently violating curfew regulations by taking on passengers. Official police sources said 42 suspected militants were detained during the clashes, but Indian news services reported as many as 170 arrests. There was no way to reconcile the conflicting reports. Among those arrested, police said, were seven ``area commanders'' of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, one of the Moslem groups leading the movement to establish a separate nation in Kashmir. Security forces have been enforcing a round-the-clock curfew in Kashmir since April 7, a day after Moslem militants kidnapped three people. The government refused the separatists' demand to release three jailed militants in exchange for the hostages. The bullet-riddled bodies of the hostages were found early last week. The United News of India news agency, quoting official sources, reported that security forces were close to arresting those responsible for the kidnapping. Since April 7, security forces have detained about 1,000 Kashmiris, mostly young men and boys, in their manhunt for the kidnappers. At least 270 people have died since January when the government launched a crackdown on Moslem separatists in the Kashmir valley. The situation has led to a deterioration in India's relations with neighboring Pakistan. The countries have fought two wars over Kashmir since gaining their independence from Britain in 1947. Moslem separatists in Kashmir say they want an independent country, attached neither to Pakistan nor India, whose population is 82 percent Hindu. India's Jammu-Kashmir state is the only state in India with a Moslem majority, with Moslems accounting for 64 percent of the state's 6 million people. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Kill Seven Policemen and Four Civilians in Two Attacks
DOC.TEXT: A police truck hit a land mine on an isolated road Sunday, killing seven officers, officials said. The officials blamed the attack on the leftist Shining Path gurrillas. The blast occured near the town of Chosica, 40 miles east of Lima, while the officers were being transported to the Andean mountain hamlet of Yanacoto. They were to replace fellow officers guarding electrical towers in the mountains. The utility towers are a prime target of the Maoist-inspired guerrillas in their decade-old insurgency. Officials also the gurrillas killed four civilians in the Andean city of Ayacucho, 200 miles southeast of Lima. The dead included a 63-year-old woman, her son, a barber and a student, who were killed between Friday night and Saturday morning when they were sleeping, police said. The government says more than 18,000 people have died since the Shining Path began its fight in 1980 in the southern Andean highlands against Peru's elected government.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew Imposed on Gaza Strip, Government Approves Jewish Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The army announced Sunday it was imposing a curfew on the occupied Gaza Strip to prevent demonstrations marking the second anniversary of the assassination of the PLO's military chief, allegedly by Israeli commandos. The curfew is scheduled to begin Monday morning and will confine the area's 800,000 residents to their homes, an army spokesman said. Also Sunday, the Defense Ministry gave final approval to a group of Jewish settlers to establish a long-planned settlement in the Gaza Strip, Israel television reported. The settlement, named Dugit, is one of eight Jewish settlements approved by the government when it took office in November 1988. Three of those settlements have already been established. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said settlers are expected to soon move into Dugit. Since capturing the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 Middle East War, Israel has built 143 settlements in the occupied territories. The area is home to 1.7 million Palestinians and some 75,000 Jews. The Palestinian uprising's clandestine leadership has called for clashes Monday to commemorate the second anniversary of the PLO leader's death. ``The underground unified leadership calls on its masses and strike forces to hold memorial marches and raise Palestinian and black flags to commemorate the death of Abu Jihad,'' a leaflet distributed last week said. Abu Jihad, Arabic for ``Father of the Holy War,'' was the nom de guerre of Khalil Wazir, the PLO's chief of military operations. Wazir was killed two years ago by a squad of commandos who burst into his home outside Tuni, Tunisia. It is widely suspected that the killing was carried out by Israelis. The Israeli military has never denied the claim. The news of his death sparked off massive riots throughout the occupied territories and especially in Gaza, where some of Wazir's relatives live. At least 673 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis since the start of the 28-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. Palestinians have killed 207 fellow Arabs during the revolt, most on suspicion as collaborators. Six Palestinians were wounded Sunday in clashes with soldiers throughout the occupied territories, Arab hospital officials said. An army spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the military had no reports of wounded and was investigating the claims.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii's Sen. Spark Matsunaga Dead of Cancer at Age 73
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 10-15, ``Sen. Daniel Inouye xxx to update with comment; edits next-to-lat graf to delete first reference to Inouye; subs 4th graf, ``The spokesman xxx to fix style of cemetery
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Spark M. Matsunaga of Hawaii, a longtime advocate for peace and champion of Japanese-Americans seeking compensation for their internment during World War II, died early Sunday in Toronto. He was 73. The late Democrat's spokesman, Ed Greaney, said in Washington that Matsunaga died about 2 a.m. He was in Toronto for cancer treatment. Greaney said the senator's body would be flown to Washington on a military aircraft Sunday and to Hawaii early this week. The spokesman said Hawaii Gov. John Waihee asked that the body lie in state Wednesday in the state Capitol. Burial would be Thursday or Friday at National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific at Punchbowl. Matsunaga, who announced in January that he was suffering from prostate cancer that had spread to the bone, died at Toronto General Hospital, according to nursing coordinator Olga Muir. The senator traveled to Canada last week for treatment at an oncology clinic, according to Greaney. The senator's wife, Helene, daughter, Merle, and son, Keene, were with him when he died, Greaney said. The senator has been plagued by medical ailments, including a heart attack in 1984, a stomach ulcer in 1987, a serious bout with the flu and back problems in 1988. Waihee, a Democrat, has authority to name a successor to serve until a special election could be held in November. Matsunaga's term runs through 1994. Rep. Daniel K. Akaka, a Hawaii Democrat elected to the House in 1976, is considered the leading choice to succeed Matsunaga. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said it is not impossible to fill another's shoes in a particular job, ``but I don't think it's possible to find someone with Sparky's touch.'' He said Akaka ``would seem to be the logical choice'' to succeed Matsunaga. Akaka refused to discuss the possibility of his appointment, saying, ``At this time my deep concern is for his family, and also in participating to create a most adequate and proper tribute for this great American. ``Sparky's death is an enormous loss for the United States and people of Hawaii. He was a great American, a peacemaker. He was distinguished militarily, politically, socially and globally. I'll remember Sparky as having a human, local Hawaiian touch when it came to politics.'' Carolyn Tanaka, press secretary to Waihee, said it would be several days before the governor began to deal with the issue of a successor. ``When I learned of Spark's passing,'' said Inouye, ``I recalled a conversation I had with him about three years ago. I asked how he would like to be remembered, and he said, `I'd like to be remembered as a friend ... a friend of the war veterans ... as a friend of the forgotten, those who have no friends ... as one who supports those who are peacemakers ... as your friend.' I said, `I'm certain you'll be remembered as a friend of Hawaii.''' Matsunaga was known more for his easygoing manner and his warm treatment of constituents than his impact on legislation. But when he cared deeply about an issue, he combined skill and perseverance to win passage. In 1988 he engineered passage of a $1.25 billion law that pays $20,000 to each surviving Japanese-American interned in a U.S. prison camp during World War II. Matsunaga, a Japanese-American who was highly decorated in World War II, had to overcome opposition to the internment law from some veterans and from those who objected to its cost. During debate, the senator was forced to halt his comments in mid-sentence while telling of an elderly internee killed by a guard as he went to pick up a softball. ``I myself become overly emotional when I think about it even to this day,'' he said after regaining his composure. Matsunaga lobbied for 22 years before persuading Congress in 1984 to establish a U.S. Peace Institute. ``Peacemaking is as much an art to be learned as war'' was his persistent argument. Matsunaga supported a joint U.S.-Soviet exploration of Mars, sponsored a plan for an International Space Year in 1992 and worked to make his state a center for space exploration. Waihee said Sunday, ``He will be remembered most for his vision of peace and his faith in the human heart. In his memory we will carry on his quest. In his spirit we will strive for the highest of principles and the brightest of worlds. ``Senator Matsunaga has been a steady and guiding force throughout Hawaii's modern history. Sparky warmed our state and country with his humanitarianism.'' Matsunaga was first elected to the House in 1962 and the Senate in 1976. When he died, he was the second-ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee and chairman of its subcommittee on taxation and debt management. Before going to Washington, Matsunaga was a member of Hawaii's territorial House from 1954 to 1959. He was born Oct. 8, 1916, on Kauai Island, the son of immigrants from Japan. After graduating from the University of Hawaii with honors in 1941, Matsunaga joined the 100th Infantry Battalion, which later became part of the famed 442nd Regimental Combat Team. The ``Go for Broke'' 442nd would become the most decorated regiment in U.S. history. Matsunaga was wounded twice during World War II. He was awarded numerous medals, including the Bronze Star and Purple Heart with cluster. Matsunaga was a member of the ``Class of '54'' _ Hawaii Democrats who came to power before statehood and established a political dynasty that continues to this day. Inouye was another member of the class. Matsunaga is survived by a wife, Helene Hatsumi Tokunaga, and five children.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Responds to Critics of Ferry Disaster Inquiry
DOC.TEXT: The judge conducting the inquiry into the Scandinavian Star ferry fire rejected charges Sunday that the proceedings were being improperly conducted. Authorities said 160 people died in the blaze, which police are investigating as a case of arson. The 20-year-old ferry caught fire April 7 in Swedish waters on an overnight trip from Norway to Denmark. Maritime unions in Norway and Sweden have criticized the hearings, now in their fifth day. They complained attorneys for the shipowners were dominating the questioning of witnesses and the captain has been allowed to attend all sessions after testifying as the first witness. The Norwegian captain, Hugo Larsen, admitted he abandoned the burning ship while some passengers remained alive on board. ``We are on the borderland of parody when representatives of the ferry owners are the ones asking questions during the inquiry,'' Norwegian sailors' union leader, Gudmund Aasheim, told the Norwegian news agency NTB. But Marine and Trade Court President Frank Poulsen, the judge heading the hearing, said, ``The proceedings are continuing in a correct and harmonious way.'' Poulsen said the inquiry came at the request of the Danish shipowner, VR Da-No Lines, and that the presence of its representatives was required by law. The judge said the purpose of the inquiry was to find the facts in the case. Witnesses are under oath and have been warned that their testimony could be used in any subsequent criminal case. Representatives of the ferry's insurers, Scandinavian marine authorities and Norwegian and Danish police are also taking part in the inquiry. About half of the expected 30 witnesses have testified. A commission of Danish, Norwegian and Swedish maritime officials also is scheduled to hold hearings on the case following the Copenhagen marine court inquiry.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Trial Raises Troubling Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3, 19,21,22 to CORRECT Klieman's sex to female, sted male.
DOC.TEXT: The Christian Science Church says its right to exist goes on trial this week with two church members charged with manslaughter for relying on prayer alone to heal their 2{-year-old son. The prosecution will argue that the David and Ginger Twitchell's son, Robyn, might be alive today had his parents sought medical attention for his bowel obstruction. The Twitchells' attorney, Rikki Klieman, said she will argue that her clients, far from acting recklessly, sought the only real cure that was dictated by their most deeply held beliefs. The U.S. Supreme Court typically has refused to hear such cases, and there has been little consensus in similar cases heard in state courts around the country: _ A Los Angeles judge in February acquitted Eliot and Lise Glaser, a Christian Scientist couple, of involuntary manslaughter in the meningitis death of their toddler son on grounds of insufficient evidence. _ In August 1989, a Santa Rosa, Calif., jury acquitted Christian Scientists Mark Rippberger and Susan Middleton of like charges in the meningitis death of their 15-month-old daughter, but convicted them of child endangerment. _ In Sarasota, Fla., a Christian Scientist husband and wife received probation for their April 1989 conviction for third-degree murder for letting their diabetic 7-year-old daughter die without receiving medical attention. On Tuesday, almost exactly four years after Robyn Twitchell's death, his parents go on trial in Suffolk District Court under the scrutiny of the Mother Church, world headquarters here of the Christian Science Church. A week before the trial was to begin, the church took out full-page ads in several Massachusetts newspapers to discuss the case and explain church doctrine. ``Why,'' the ads ask, ``is prayer being prosecuted in Boston?'' John Kiernan, a special assistant district attorney, denies the case is an attack on Christian Science or a repudiation of spiritual healing. He said it has nothing to do with freedom of religion. ``The whole idea is to bring to the front: `What is the required conduct of parents?''' he said. ``We are advocates of children. We are not persecutors of religious beliefs.'' When Robyn apparently came down with the flu, the Twitchells followed church teaching and called a Christian Scientist practitioner and Christian Scientist nurse to treat him, said church spokesman Nathan Talbot. After four days in which the illness ``ebbed and flowed,'' Klieman said, the boy appeared to get better. A day before he died, she said, he went outside to play. Kiernan argued that an adult may choose to forgo conventional medical treatment, but a child is not in a position to make such a decision. ``The medical profession is quite clear this condition is relatively easy to diagnose and the prescribed treatment has a very, very high success rate,'' he said. By relying exclusively on Christian Science healing, the Twitchells acted with reckless disregard for the health of their son, he said. The state, he contends, has a duty to protect children. ``(Religious) practice is subject to regulation by the state. Belief is not. ... There's a whale of a difference, particularly when dealing with a baby,'' he said. The church, founded in 1879 by Mary Baker Eddy, believes that physical disease, like sin, can be healed by spiritual means alone. There are about 2,600 Christian Science churches in 68 countries and the church owns weekly and monthly publications and a television news show. Klieman contends prejudice against the Christian Science church lies at the heart of the case. ``This district attorney wants to put the Christian Scientists out of business,'' she said. ``Oh, good lord, no,'' Kiernan responded, reiterating that the heart of the issue was parental conduct. Klieman said her clients ``chose a system of health care ... which they believed was excellent,'' adding that Christian Science practitioners' care is covered by Blue Cross and Medicare and is tax deductible. She also has argued that a 1971 amendment to state child abuse and neglect law recognizes spiritual healing as an alternative to modern medicine, but gives Christian Scientists no guidance on when a physician must be called. Harvard divinity professor Harvey Cox said the case demonstrates the difficulty in setting the limits of religious freedom. ``There's a feeling within the religious community that the degree of state involvement and supervision has gone too far,'' Cox said. Yet accommodations have been worked out, he said, pointing to the Amish community, which repudiates modern practices, but coexists with a modern state. Perhaps the middle ground in the Twitchell case will be carved out by a legal recognition of alternative forms of healing, he said.

DOC.HEAD: President To Announce Plans For Scrapping Apartheid Laws
DOC.TEXT: A leading newspaper reported Sunday that President F.W. de Klerk plans to make a ``statement of intent'' this week to eliminate remaining apartheid laws. The Sunday Star of Johannesburg, citing ``political insiders,'' said de Klerk was expected to outline his plans in a speech to Parliament. De Klerk has initiated a series of reforms of South Africa's system of racial segregation since assuming power in August. He says he wants to dismantle apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that will include the country's 28 million blacks. He opposes a one-man, one-vote system, however, saying it will replace white domination with black domination. He also has not spelled out his position on several major apartheid laws. They include the Group Areas Act, which segregates neighborhoods by race; the Population Registration Act, which classifies all South Africans by race; and the Land Acts, which allocate 13 percent of the land for blacks, who make up 75 percent of the population. The Sunday Star quoted sources as saying that de Klerk is likely to make a ``statement of intent'' this week to do away with these measures, but is not expected to scrap them unilaterally. He apparently would prefer to negotiate the final details with opposition groups, the newspaper reported. The newspaper quoted an unidentified member of Parliament as saying: ``We are now telling our people _ and they accept it _ that the next government will be mainly black.'' The Star said the speech has been timed to increase the momentum of political reform heading into groundbreaking talks with the African National Congress guerrilla movement scheduled for May 2-4. The discussions are designed to clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution. Constitutional negotiations would include several opposition groups in addition to the ANC, the government has said. De Klerk legalized the ANC and more than 60 other anti-apartheid groups in February as part of his effort to launch black-white power-sharing talks. The same month, he freed black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela from prison. Mandela, deputy president of the ANC, had been imprisoned 27 years. He was convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturer Says Pipes Cannot Be Joined To Make Gun For Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Eight huge steel tubes seized while en route to Iraq could not be joined together to form a giant gun or make up part of a space satellite launch system, their manufacturer said Sunday. A spokesman for Sheffield Forgemasters reiterated the company had contracted only to supply Iraq with forged steel tubing for a petrochemical plant. British government sources were quoted late Saturday as saying the pipes match the specifications for a satellite launch system designed by Dr. Gerald Bull, an American ballistics expert killed in Brussels, Belgium last month. Press Association, the domestic British news agency, quoted the unnamed sources as saying they had correspondence linking British industry with Space Research Projects, the Brussels firm which Bull owned. Press Association did not name the government department of the sources, but The Sunday Telegraph, The Sunday Times, and the Observer all carried articles quoting Customs sources on the same subject. The pipes were seized last week by British customs officials who suspected they were parts for a massive gun barrel. ``Nobody seems to have taken on board the fact that those eight pieces do not join up to form one piece,'' said Forgemasters spokesman Tony Peck. ``They are random selections of tubes from a consignment of 26 which, added together, measure 156 meters (170 yards). They cannot join them together.'' Sheffield Forgemasters says it agreed to supply 52 sections of the steel tubing and had delivered 44 to the Ministry of Industry and Minerals in the Iraqi capital of Baghdad. Iraq has also claimed the metal tubes were pipes for a petrochemical plant. Arms experts have given conflicting opinions about whether the steel sections could be used as a weapon. Peck said the company had permission from the Department of Trade and Industry to manufacture the tubing and sell it to Iraq. The department refused to comment Sunday. Britain banned all arms sales to Iraq and Iran after the outbreak of their eight-year Persian Gulf War. Despite the 1988 cease-fire, the embargo remains in effect. Bull, 62, a Canadian-born American citizen, was slain March 22. Belgian police said he was shot twice in the head by an assailant using a silencer. They said the motive was not robbery because $20,000 was found in the victim's pockets. Bull's company was engaged in space and military research and international arms sales. Western fears about Iraqi arms programs have grown in recent weeks. On March 28, British customs officials seized U.S.-made parts for atomic bomb triggers that were bound for Iraq. Iraq has confirmed it has chemical weapons, but has denied seeking a nuclear capability. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein recently threatened to use missiles armed with chemical warheads against Israel if Israeli forces attacked his country.

DOC.HEAD: Government Denies Guerrillas Hold Territory
DOC.TEXT: The government on Sunday denied reports that rebels controlled any part of the West African nation. ``No inch of this nation is under the control of the rebels,'' said Information Minister Emmanuel Bowier. Bowier said journalists who claim to have visited rebel bases in Liberia were actually in Guinea or Ivory Coast. Recent visitors to the Nimba Country area, which was invaded from the Ivory Coast by rebels led by Charles Taylor on Dec. 24, have said the guerrillas are largely in control of the region. Taylor's forces are seeking to overthrow President Samuel Doe. Bowier, in a news briefing Sunday, said government troops had brought the situation in Nimba under control. On Saturday, Brig. Gen. Charles Julu said Taylor's hiding place had been surrounded and said his troops killed 100 rebels when they tried to retake Ganta, the Nimba capital. He did not say when the fighting took place, and there was no independent confirmation of his claims. On Sunday, Julu said there had been no fighting overnight. He said the county's main towns were in government hands. Julu said nothing about Taylor. The fighting in Nimba has sent more than 150,000 people fleeing into Guinea and Ivory Coast, which border the county. International organizations have accused Liberian troops of killing hundreds of civilians in trying to put down the rebellion. Guerrilla forces were accused of killing members of Doe's Krahn tribe in reprisal for the government killings. Doe, a former army sergeant, seized power in a 1980 military coup.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Official Found Slain in Papua New Guinea
DOC.TEXT: The country's former chief police and prison official was stabbed to death Sunday at his Port Moresby home, police said. Police said three assailants killed Pius Kerepia, who resigned in December following a campaign by senior officials against his attempts to reform the corrections department and transfer officers. Metropolitan Police Chief Supt. Phillip Taku said the stabbing was being treated as an assassination. ``It was not robbery,'' Taku said. Kerepia was stabbed in the neck and the left side of the chest, said police sources quoted by the Australian Associated Press. Taku said at least 30 people had been detained for questioning, but no one had been charged with the slaying. The news agency said senior officers last year circulated a petition accusing Kerepia's administration of corruption and sexual scandal, but an investigation into the allegations has not been completed. After stepping down, Kerepia continued to maintain a high profile as a member of a government discussion group set up to resolve a revolt on the copper-rich island of Bougainville. Landowners who are demanding compensation from the government over one of the world's largest copper mines have fought with government troops for almost a year. Kerepia was Papua New Guinea's first police commissioner at independence in 1975, and he later served as secretary of the department of works before being appointed corrective services commissioner in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Links Chemical Pollution to Birth Defect Causes
DOC.TEXT: A negligence lawsuit stemming from a deadly explosion at a chemical plant has produced evidence linking pollution to Down's syndrome. Between 1980 and 1985, six children were born with Down's syndrome in this small Panhandle area. The Texas Department of Health and U.S. Centers for Disease Control have said the number is ``significantly more than expected'' in a population of 25,000. The agencies found no cause for the birth defects. More than 250 people from Pampa and nearby Kingsmill have joined a lawsuit against Hoechst Celanese Corp., alleging negligence in three deaths and numerous injuries from a 1987 explosion at its chemical plant. On Friday, Dr. John Denko, an Amarillo pathologist, submitted a report to state District Court in Houston in the lawsuit, saying the number of Down's cases probably ``is related to the environmental pollutants from the Celanese site.'' Another Pampa area doctor told the court in a letter obtained by The Pampa News that in 1985 he noted ``something most unusual'' in the number of Down's cases in the area. Dr. Gerald H. Holman of the Growth and Genetics Program for Infants, Children and Adolescents in Amarillo said he was concerned about ``alarming'' levels of environmental pollution and related health problems. Vernon Hartline, an attorney for Celanese, said the company's tests show environmental factors have nothing to do with the Down's cases. On Friday, Celanese offered findings by three doctors who said, ``It is uncertain whether one of the children discussed by Dr. Denko even has Down's syndrome.'' ``The so-called `general health epidemic' is, in large part, merely an amalgamation of a number of health conditions that have nothing to do with one another,'' the report said. It said the incidence of Down's cases in Pampa are ``for the most part absolutely normal,'' and any increase is due ``as likely as anything else, to chance.'' The U.S. rate of Down's syndrome cases among young women is one in 1,500 and for women in their late 20s and early 30s about one in 1,000. In the 1980s, the number of births among Pampa women was 347 to 484 a year. Because of the low number of births, no more than two Down's syndrome babies should have been born between 1980-85, Holman said. Plaintiffs in the lawsuit have asked to be considered a class, but the court hasn't ruled on the motion.

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies After Awakening to Burglar
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian tourist dropped dead in his motel room after a burglar intruded, and a 19-year-old man was arrested on burglary and theft charges, state police said Sunday. A burglar late Saturday entered a Concorde Motel first-floor window near the head of the bed in which Tyler J. Crandall, 45, of Knowlton, Quebec, and his wife, Donna, were sleeping, said state police spokesman Stephen McCausland. As the burglar entered, Crandall's wife ``awakened, saw a man coming in and screamed,'' McCausland said, and her husband got out of bed, collapsed and died. The burglar fled. Crandall's body was taken to a Biddeford hospital for an autopsy. Five state police detectives were called in along with the state attorney general's office, which investigates possible homicides. Adrien S. Veilleux, 19, of Buxton was arrested early Sunday after two other burglaries were reported at a condominium only blocks from the motel. Police called to the scene and using a tracking dog arrested Veilleux seven blocks away, McCausland said. Veilleu was being held on three counts of burglary and two of theft.

DOC.HEAD: Police Making Drug Arrest Find Dead Infant in Car Trunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to specify charges; tightens; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police found the body of an infant in the trunk of a car after stopping the driver to make a narcotics arrest, authorities said Sunday. The infant was wrapped in several layers of cloth, and appeared to have been dead for several days, police said. The driver, Mary Sue Perkins, 30, of Wilton, was arrested Saturday night and charged with posession of narcotics, interfering with a police officer, attempted assault and destruction of evidence, according to a police statement. Police would not say Sunday whether Perkins was believed to be the infant's mother, and the drugs allegedly involved were not identified. Police also charged her with reckless driving and driving with a suspended license. The state medical examiner's office is to conduct an autopsy Monday. Perkins was being held on $75,000 bond at the Norwalk police station, pending arraignment Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes Near Hindu Temple, Killing Five
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden in a tractor exploded outside a Hindu temple Sunday, killing five people and injuring 25 as they watched a popular television show at a nearby TV shop, police said. The police blamed Sikh militants. In addition, 11 suspected Sikh militants were killed throughout the northwestern state of Punjab, Press Trust of India reported. Sikh separatists, claiming discrimination by Hindus who dominate the government, have killed about 570 people so far this year in their campaign for a separate homeland for their religious sect. The bomb exploded in the Punjab town of Ludhiana after a Sikh man parked the tractor, Ludhiana Police Superintendent H.S. Khera said. The dead included a Sikh shopkeeper and a Sikh woman and her 8-year-old grandson who had come to watch the television show, Khera said. The faiths of the other victims were not immediately known. No one was in the temple at the time of the blast, Khera said. The victims were among a crowd of about 50 people who had gathered to watch a popular TV serial at the shop beside the temple gate, Khera said. In the past, Sikh extremists have planted bombs near TV shops and timed them to explode when crowds gather for the weekly showing of ``Mahabharata.'' The long-running Hindu epic draws vast audiences of all faiths throughout India. Khera said a Sikh man in his early 20s parked the tractor beside the temple gate at 9 a.m., 15 minutes before the show began. About 10 minutes later, the tractor caught fire and while some of the crowd tried to extinguish it, the bomb exploded, Khera said. Ludhiana, 70 miles southeast of Amritsar, has a mixed Hindu and Sikh population. Amritsar is the capital of Punjab, which borders Pakistan. Press Trust of India reported that 11 suspected Sikh militants were killed throughout the state since Saturday night. Six of the militants were killed in a shootout with security forces in Tarn Taran, the report said. One suspected separatist was apparently killed in inter-gang rivalry, it said, while the remaining four were killed in separate incidents around the state. The report could not be confirmed immediately. Sikhs have a slight majority in Punjab, but nationwide they make up only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. The militants claim they are discriminated against culturally and politically by Hindus, who dominate the government and make up 82 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela To Thank Supporters at Huge Pop Concert
LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 12th graf pvs, `Mrs. Thatcher...' to UPDATE with reports that Mandela saying he intends to meet Thatcher later this year, reports that De Klerk plans to rescind apartheid laws. Pickup pvs 13th graf, ``About 72,000...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela is to take center stage in a televised pop concert Monday at Wembley Stadium to thank millions of people around the world for supporting him and the fight to end apartheid in South Africa. Mandela was imprisoned in South Africa when 70,000 spectators filled the stadium nearly two years ago to mark his 70th birthday. Twenty top performers are scheduled to play at Monday's concert, including Grammy Award-winner Bonnie Raitt, Neil Young, Soul II Soul, The Neville Brothers, Simple Minds, Miriam Makeba, Peter Gabriel, Anita Baker and Tracy Chapman. Among those attending are U.S. Democratic politician Jesse Jackson and Neil Kinnock, leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, has not accepted an invitation to meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, an outspoken opponent of sanctions against South Africa's white-led government. Mandela, now 71, was released in February after spending 27 years in prison. He was convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. The ANC leader, accompanied by his wife, Winnie, arrived in London early Sunday on his first visit to Britain since 1962, the year he was arrested. ``It is an honor and a pleasure for me and my delegation to be on British soil,'' he told reporters at Heathrow Airport. ``We have always looked forward to this occasion, an occasion when we can thank the British people for the support which they have given us in the cause of our anti-apartheid struggle,'' he said. Mandela was quoted as telling Press Association, the domestic British news agency, that the sole purpose of his two-day visit was to attend Monday night's sold-out concert at north London's Wembley Stadium. ``I won't be meeting any British politician as far as I am aware. This is not to single out Mrs. Thatcher,'' Mandela was quoted as saying before leaving his home in the black South African township of Soweto. The British government has had almost no contact with the ANC and that policy has not changed, a Thatcher spokesman said. Mrs. Thatcher has consistently resisted most sanctions against Pretoria, saying they would hurt the black majority more than the ruling white minority. After Mandela's Feb. 11 release from prison, Mrs. Thatcher urged international sanctions be eased to encourage South African President F. W. de Klerk to make more reforms. Britain unilaterally lifted a ban on new investment in South Africa. In reports issued late Sunday, the BBC and the British domestic press agency, Press Association, said Mandela intends to meet with Mrs. Thatcher later this year. They quoted Karen Talbot, spokeswoman for the British-based Anti-Apartheid Movement. There was no response from Mrs. Thatcher's office. Also Sunday, a leading South African newspaper, the Sunday Star of Johannesburg, reported President F.W. de Klerk plans to make a ``statement of intent'' to South Africa's Parliament this week to eliminate remaining apartheid laws. The newspaper reported de Klerk is not expected to scrap the measures unilaterally, but apparently would prefer to negotiate the final details with opposition groups. About 72,000 people have paid $33 each to attend the four-hour concert titled ``Nelson Mandela _ An International Tribute for a Free South Africa.'' Mandela is scheduled to speak near the end of the show. The concert will be beamed live or by taped delay to 26 countries, but not to South Africa, where concert organizers are upholding sanctions against the South African Broadcasting Corp. Neither will it be seen in the United States, concert organizers said. They said U.S. television networks turned it down as too political, but there was no immediate comment by U.S. network officials. The concert's organizers _ the Nelson Mandela International Reception Committee and Freedom Productions _ said 50 percent of the profits will be donated to six charities. On June 11, 1988, more than 70,000 people attended the 10-hour Wembley rock concert honoring Mandela. It was broadcast to an estimated 750 million people in 60 countries, including the United States.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Killed in Northern Philippine Battle
DOC.TEXT: Communist and government forces clashed in a northern province and 11 rebels and one soldier were killed, the military said Sunday. A military communique said at least five other government soldiers were wounded during the pre-dawn battle Saturday in the mountain town of Rizal in Cagayan province, 220 miles north of Manila. The rebels belonged to the New People's Army which has been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Rainy Easter Sunday Across America
DOC.TEXT: Thundershowers and rain made Easter Sunday a damp holiday in sections of the West, East and Midwest, and the weather was unseasonably cool in the upper Midwest. Scattered snow fell in northeast Minnesota and northeast upper Michigan. Heavy rain fell in southeast New York state. Between 2 a.m. and 8 a.m. EDT, the New York City area received up to 1.35 inches of rain. But by afternoon, the rain had moved out over the Atlantic Ocean. Rain showers Sunday afternoon reached from Maine to New Jersey. Rain and occasional thundershowers fell on eastern North Carolina. Rain showers and thunderstorms extended over eastern North Carolina, and from northeast Oklahoma to southeast Kansas, southern Missouri and northern Arkansas. In Tulsa, Okla., thunderstorms produced small hail and gusty winds. Rain showers also extended over eastern Missouri, southern Illinois, southwest Indiana and southeast Lower Michigan, as well as in northeast Montana, along the northern coast of California and the southern coast of Oregon. Temperatures were unseasonably low in the northern Plains and the upper Mississippi Valley. In Huron, S.D., the mercury dropped to a record 17 degrees. The old mark for the date was 18 degrees in 1962. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 33 degrees in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 93 degrees in Phoenix. DOC.HEAD: Basque Nationalists Mark National Day
DOC.TEXT: Basque political leaders on Sunday called for an independent state as thousands marked the national day of the violence-torn region. Police said more than 20,000 people attended rallies held by the northern three-province region's four main nationalist parties, which hold 53 of 75 seats in the regional parliament. ``These are manifestations of a single reality _ our will to be a nation and to decide our fate by ourselves,'' said regional parliament leader Jose Antonio Ardanza in San Sebastian. The rallies commemorated Aberri Eguna, which translates from the ancient Basque language as Day Of The Basque Motherland. More than 10,000 people sang the Basque national anthem and chanted pro-independence slogans at a march in Pamplona, capital of the neighboring region of Navarre. Some nationalists want Navarre to be part of any future Basque state. Ardanza, addressing a rally in San Sebastian attended by thousands of members of his Basque Nationalist Party, criticized his Socialist coalition partners for failing to support a pro-independence proclamation signed Feb. 15 by the his party and three others. Another proclamation in 1987 denounced terrorism. The only regional party that refused to sign the terrorism proclamation was the Herri Batasuna, widely considered the political arm of the armed separatist group ETA. ETA has claimed responsibility for nearly all of the more than 600 killings in political violence in 22 years. Under Spain's 1978 constitution, the three Basque provinces, which have more than 2.1 million inhabitants, form one of the countries 17 ``autonomous communities.'' But their true autonomy is limited since they are dependent on the Madrid government for nearly all their funds and lack formal representation in a national legislative body.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says U.S. Charity Should Start At Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-12 pvs, `Abraham Foxman...' to CORRECT title, second reference; picks up 13th pvs, `Dole has...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said Sunday that the United States has to take care of its own homeless before granting Israel's request for loans to house Soviet Jewish immigrants. ``Charity starts at home and that means America,'' Dole, R-Kan., told a news conference. ``We are going to give $400 million to Israel for housing guarantees when we have 3 million homeless in America and no program for them?'' he asked rhetorically. Dole has been the Bush administration's point man in attempts to reduce foreign aid. Israel is already the largest recipient of such funding, getting about $3 billion a year. The Jewish state is seeking the $400 million in U.S.-government guaranteed housing loans to help absorb the onslaught of Soviet Jewish immigrants. Israeli officials say as many as 500,000 may arrive over the next three years. The prospect of mass immigration has angered the Arab world ever since Israel's caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir suggested earlier this year that Israel needed to retain the occupied lands to settle the wave of Soviet Jews. President Bush made any U.S. aid for immigration purposes conditional on an Israeli guarantee that the money would not help settle Soviet Jews in territory Israel occupied during the 1967 Middle East War, including east Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Bush said in early March that the United States didn't recognize Israel's annexation of the eastern half of Jerusalem. Israel has declared unified Jerusalem its capital, and most Palestinians want east Jerusalem as the capital of an independent Palestinian state. The Senate passed a non-binding resolution March 22 confirming that Jerusalem should be Israel's capital. Dole protested the Senate decision and said he was going to state his position on the Senate floor this week. ``I conclude (the resolution) was ill-timed,'' he said. ``All it does is stir up rhetoric. The Arab countries only wanted to discuss the resolution and not the peace process.'' Dole claimed that Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek had agreed that the Senate decision came at a bad time and served no useful purpose. Kollek could not immediately be reached for comment. Abraham Foxman, U.S. director of the B'nai B'rith's Anti-Defamation League, called Dole's intention to protest the Senate resolution ``insulting.'' ``It is inconceivable that he should lead a campaign based on a chorus of criticism in the Arab world,'' Foxman said in a statement released in Jerusalem Sunday. Dole has headed a delegation of five U.S. senators whose visit to Israel was the last stop on a Middle East tour to promote peace. Other countries on the itinerary included Egypt, Syria, Jordan and Iraq. The group was scheduled to return to Washington on Sunday. Others in the delegation were James McClure, R-Idaho; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska; and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. The senators, reflecting on Israel's current political crisis, stressed that the country urgently needed a government that would launch peace talks with the Palestinians. Metzenbaum criticized the Israeli electoral system that is stalling government formation and said he was leaving with no more optimism for peace. Metzenbaum saw no readiness for arms control in the Middle East and said that international supervison over the weapons industry was not even discussed with Shamir. However, Murkowski, who earlier celebrated Easter Sunday in a Jerusalem church, had a more optimistic message: ``This is really what Easter is all about, an opportunity for a new beginning,'' he said. ``I think we leave with that challenge and communicate that challenge to you.''

DOC.HEAD: Easter Celebrations: A Dirge and a Chorus of Hallelujah
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quake survivor taking part in egg hunt, prayers said for hostages in Lebanon, editing; no pickup.
