With AM-Easter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Charlton Heston read Scripture at the Hollywood Bowl, and gay activists wearing veils in memory of AIDS victims joined the traditional parade along New York's Fifth Avenue as millions of Americans celebrated Easter Sunday. A boy whose leg was amputated during the San Francisco Bay earthquake hunted Easter eggs, thousands of homeless people received free meals and prayers were said for the release of hostages held in Lebanon. Many celebrated Easter by attending services or attending family reunions. In Southern California, sunrise services drew thousands of people, but in Chicago only about 100 shivering worshipers showed up before dawn for lakefront services. At the 70th annual sunrise service at the Hollywood Bowl, Heston, who portrayed Moses in the movie ``The Ten Commandments'' and Judah Ben Hur in ``Ben Hur,'' read the Bible. Actress Connie Stevens recited an Easter poem from a stage festooned with flowers. Chants of ``Hallelujah'' wafted down from the Hollywood Hills to the Los Angeles basin below. The spectacle, broadcast worldwide, included a tribute to new religious freedom in Eastern Europe and closed with the release of hundreds of white ``birds of peace.'' More earthly needs were addressed on Los Angeles' Skid Row. The Union Rescue Mission dished up 1,500 pancake breakfasts and hundreds of needy children received Easter baskets, spokesman Alex Akar said. Missions expected to serve dinner to more than 10,000 people. In Baltimore, several hundred homeless people sat down at St. Andrew's Orthodox Church to an Easter supper of ham with all the trimmings. ``Easter is the most important day for the Orthodox Church,'' said parishioner Suzanne Stratton. The Chicago Christian Industrial League served Easter dinner to hundreds of homeless people and others who gathered at the 80-year-old organization's South Side shelter complex. The Little Brothers-Friends of the Elderly prepared noon meals for about 1,500 elderly people, about half at their homes. At New York's famed Plaza Hotel, owner Donald Trump and his wife, Ivana, patched up their highly publicized marital differences long enough to greet guests at a fund-raiser for AIDS victims. At one point, the two were seen holding hands while ascending the grand ballroom steps. Mrs. Trump, who manages the Plaza, posed with two people costumed as ``Mr. and Mrs. Bunny'' on the front steps of hotel as she viewed a parade by 20 models of spring fashions by top designers. ``... We are trying to think of tradition, but people have to join forces against AIDS,'' said Mrs. Trump. Part of Fifth Avenue was closed for the traditional Easter parade Sunday morning. Some of the hundreds of strollers wore frills and bonnets, but most wore raincoats and umbrellas because of threatening weather. About 25 to 30 gay activists carrying dark umbrellas and wearing black veils and hats marched along the avenue beating a drum shrouded in black in memory of AIDS victims. They maintain the city is not providing enough money for AIDS research. At St. Patrick's Cathedral, Roman Catholic Cardinal John J. O'Connor told reporters his Easter wish was for peace across America. ``We so desperately need it. I think an awful lot of good people are trying to bring it about,'' O'Connor said. ``The crime rate continues to soar; the murders occur on the map all over the country; the violence attributable to crack and other reasons. I think an awful lot of people are desperate for peace.'' Among those seeking peace were families of the eight American hostages being held in Beirut. In Norristown, Pa., the family of Joseph Cicippio lit candles and prayed as a priest blessed a shrine to the hostages. One by one, family members carrying candles and photographs of the hostages walked solemnly to billboards erected on the lawn at the home of Cicippio's brother, Thomas. Cicippio was abducted Sept. 12, 1986. ``To be in prison is bad. To be forgotten is worse,'' said the Rev. Bede Ferrara. ``We are here to send the word ... that we in America care.'' In Richmond, Calif., the injured boy, 6-year-old Julio Berumen, took part in an egg hunt just two weeks after he began walking on his own with the help of a prosthesis and metal brace, said his grandfather, Ricardo Berumen. Julio's mother was among 42 people killed when Interstate 880 collapsed during the Oct. 17 earthquake. Doctors amputated one leg to free him from the wreckage.

DOC.HEAD: Multiparty System Is First Step, But Doubts Linger
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with talks failing, protesters refusing to let politicians leave site of talks. Pickup pvs 5th graf, ``Tens of...' ^By VIJAY JOSHI
DOC.TEXT: People power scaled the majestic Himalayas last week and a king bowed to a street revolution, promising multiparty democracy. A political stalemate is holding up the reform, however, and some fear Nepal's movement toward freedom will be turned back. Early Monday, negotiations between opposition and government leaders collapsed and hundreds of angry protesters camped out around the site of the talks, refusing to let the politicians leave. On April 8, two days after the bloodiest crackdown in Nepal's modern history, 44-year-old King Birendra gave in to the popular revolt, declared the press to be free and released political prisoners. Tens of thousands of Nepalis, their faces painted red in celebration, danced through the streets of the capital, shouting ``Victory! Victory!'' Their tears of joy dried quickly. The 17 million people in this landlocked nation of breathtaking beauty face serious questions. How can they establish true democracy in a country where the king is all-powerful and viewed by many as a living god? What means should they use? The questions are not new. Three decades ago, Nepal experimented with multiparty politics for 18 months. The experiment ended abruptly when Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed the government and banned political parties, which he accused of corruption and incompetence. Now the Nepali Congress Party, which Mahendra banned, has returned to haunt his son. Joining with a leftist coalition, the party led the movement for democracy that drew hundreds of thousands of people into the streets. Doctors, pilots, government workers, students and intellectuals conducted strikes. The movement peaked April 6 and the goverment cracked down. Up to 200 people were killed when police opened fire in Katmandu and elsewhere. Two days later, a special television broadcast told the story: The king was establishing a multiparty system. In exchange, the opposition announced an end to its agitation. New battle lines have been drawn since then. After the television announcement, Birendra invited the opposition to join an interim government that would prepare for elections. Foreign Minister Pashupati Rana said the king's role would be diminished. Opposition parties balked and have threatened to return to the streets unless the king dissolves the partyless National Assemby, or Rashtriya Panchayat, and scraps the constitution. Under the system established by his father, Birendra dominates the government. He appoints one-fifth of the National Assembly and has a say in the nomination of candidates for the other, elected seats. The constitution gives him control of the executive, legislative and judicial branches of government. Observers say the opposition's first job will be among the most difficult: to nullify, or at least limit, the king's power. ``We have scored a victory, no doubt, but we have not staged a French Revolution,'' said Dilli Raj Regmi, co-founder of the Nepali Congress Party. ``The scenario has not totally changed and we still have limited rights.'' He described the monarchy as ``useless.'' The opposition ``held all the trump cards and should have demanded dissolution of the Panchayat and the abolition of the constitution'' from the beginning, said Lok Raj Baral, a professor of political science at Tribhuvan University, the only one in Nepal. Unless the opposition acts quickly, Baral said, the result will be ``the same old game of palace intrigue,'' a reference to Birendra's past record of playing one political group against another. Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, president of the Nepali Congress Party, said ``we have to go step-by-step.'' The agitation was stopped to avoid further bloodshed and because ``we are a responsible party,'' he said. Bhattarai added, however, that if he ``does not meet our demands, the king will lose his crown.'' He said Birendra's concession is only the first step toward wider democracy that can be achieved only after general elections. There are no indications when elections will be held. ``We are willing to wait one month, one year or three years or ad infinitum,'' Bhattarai said. Others might not share his patience. Nepal, with a per capita gross national product of about $160 a year, is one of world's poorest countries and 75 percent of the people are illiterate. During the crackdown April 6, tens of thousands of angry men threw rocks and sticks at police, set fire to government buildings and smashed windows throughout the capital. Baral said: ``The people now are ready to assert their rights because they have tasted the power of mass movement. Once the people's movement has started, no army or police can stop them.''

DOC.HEAD: Trumps Together on Easter Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Donald Trump was at his wife Ivana's side during an AIDS fund-raiser at The Plaza hotel Sunday, apparently the first time the couple have been seen together in public since their much-publicized split. The Trumps later held hands as they ascended the stairway from the hotel's grand ballroom to a suite where they shared an Easter Sunday lunch with their children and in-laws, said a hotel employee speaking on condition of anonymity. After the lunch the two left The Plaza together. Mrs. Trump runs the famed hotel next to Central Park. The appearance came amid an escalating legal battle over the Trumps' split, which has been the subject of front-page stories in New York tabloids since it was disclosed in February. Last week, Mrs. Trump's lawyers asked permission to question Marla Maples, the woman with whom Trump has been linked, and sought to limit Trump's access to his wife's diaries and correspondence from him to her. Mrs. Trump's lawyers filed a lawsuit last month challenging Trump's claim that she waived her right to half his fortune _ estimated at as much as $5 billion _ in a series of postnuptial agreements, the last signed in 1987. Trump's attorneys say the agreement, which gives Mrs. Trump $10 million and their $12 million mansion in Greenwich, Conn., is ironclad.

DOC.HEAD: Lord Bruce-Gardyne, Former Treasury Minister, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Baron John Bruce-Gardyne, a former treasury official in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's first administration, died Sunday after a long illness, the prime minister's office said. He was 60. The cause of death was not announced, but he underwent surgery for a brain tumor last year. Bruce-Gardyne, known as Jock, was a fierce advocate of monetarist policies and served as treasury minister for 21 months for Mrs. Thatcher. He served as minister of state in 1981 and economic secretary from 1981-83. ``He was a marvelous colleague, loyal, but always retaining an independent mind,'' Mrs. Thatcher said Sunday. ``He was never afraid to challenge orthodoxy although it was always done with good humor. He was among the first in the Conservative Party to rediscover the importance of monetary policy and of encouraging market forces and competition. ``He will be remembered, too, as a fine journalist, clear, incisive and witty,'' she said. ``The astonishing courage and cheerfulness with which he faced his final months won the hearts of all his friends.'' An avid cyclist, Bruce-Gardyne refused his ministerial car on most occasions and travelled around London on what the Times called ``a deplorable old bicycle.'' He was forced to stop riding his bicycle in early 1989 when his illness was discovered. Born to an old Scottish land-owning family, Bruce-Gardyne was educated at Winchester school and Oxford University's Magdalen College. He joined the diplomatic service and worked in London and Sofia, Bulgaria, from 1953 to 1956 until quitting the foreign services for journalism. Bruce-Gardyne worked as Paris correspondent for the Financial Times before going into politics. He was elected as a Conservative member of Parliament from 1964 to 1974, and again from 1979 to 1983, when boundary changes dissolved his district. After failing to win nomination for the next election, he retired from Parliament and was created a life peer. Bruce-Gardyne continued to work, largely as a political and financial commentator, and spoke about his illness. ``Nothing could be more absurd than to say it is brave of me,'' Bruce-Gardyne said recently. ``To bang out an article on my typewriter is like saying it's brave for an alcoholic to take another swig of whiskey.'' Bruce-Gardyne is survived by his wife, Sarah, and two sons and a daughter. There was no immediate information on funeral services.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaiian, Alaskan Volcanoes Active
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Hawaii's Kilauea Volcano destroyed another home Sunday and threatened 60 more, and Redoubt Volcano in Alaska erupted again but caused little disruption. A Kilauea lava flow destroyed a home in Kalapana around 11 a.m. It was the 80th home burned to the ground since Kilauea began its latest eruption seven years ago. Another lava flow was headed toward 60 homes in a Kalapana subdivision, and an evacuation notice was posted for residents there, said Hawaii Island Civil Defense spokesman Lanny Nakano. The notice urges residents to leave their homes because they may be destroyed within 24 hours. ``We have to protect residents, that's our concern now,'' Nakano said. By midday Sunday, a lava flow from the north was about 150 yards from the next home in the subdivision, Nakano said. Another flow from the west was running alongside a flow that destroyed two homes in the subdivision last week, he said. Some residents were fleeing their homes but others were holding out, Nakano said. Barricades were being extended several miles to keep the curious away from the area. Damage from Kilauea, which began its current eruption in January 1983, is estimated at more than $20 million. In Alaska, Redoubt's latest blast sent ash more than seven miles into the sky, but winds carried it away from Anchorage, Alaska Volcano Observatory officials said. Redoubt is 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. The eruption, classified as moderate, occurred at 2:49 p.m. Business continued as usual Sunday at Anchorage International Airport, officials said. A series of eruptions around Christmas slowed or diverted holiday air traffic and mail. Sunday's was the first sizable eruption since April 7. Redoubt erupted in mid-December after slumbering for 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern European Interns Get Eye-Opening Experience in Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs graf 11, ``Both Krukowski xxx to CORRECT spelling of Krakow
DOC.TEXT: The halls of Congress have become one big laboratory for a handful of Eastern Europeans who are spending three months learning how democracy works _ or doesn't work, as the case may be. ``I didn't realize the Congress works so slowly to make policy,'' said Miroslaw Luczka, a member of the Polish senate's investigations bureau in Warsaw. ``Capitol Hill is not as simple as I thought,'' said Luczka, who as an intern with the Senate Budget Committee has been following the tortuous legislative course of President Bush's request for $800 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua. ``They probably won't get that money for months,'' said Luczka. The measure has yet to be approved by the Senate. For the interns _ most of them Poles _ learning the nuts and bolts of Congress has been an eye-opening experience. Several of them have had a chance to visit congressional districts and attend town meetings. And Slawomir Gorecki, 30, had a hand in helping to draft legislation that Rep. David Dreier, R-Calif., will introduce to encourage investment in Eastern Europe. Overall, they say their stay has been informative, useful and pleasant _ with a couple of exceptions. Marian Lemke, assigned to the offices of Rep. Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., and Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., said he was gun-shy about the press after a magazine reporter quoted him out of context. ``But I'm willing to try again.'' They've also been surprised by certain things, such as the power and size of congressional staffs. ``I didn't realize Capitol Hill was such a big machine employing 44,000,'' said Marek Krukowski, 30, who spent time in the office of Rep. Larry Craig, R-Idaho. Both Krukowski and Zdobyslaw Milewski, a teacher in Krakow, were shocked by the amount of power lawmakers turn over to their staff. ``They are so dependent on their staff,'' Krukowski said. ``In Poland, politicians rely on their own knowledge.'' His colleague said he can't get used to seeing staffers sign a boss' name to a letter or document. They also wonder at the hectic life of a member of Congress. Milewski, 33, has worked in the offices of Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., and Rep. Paul Kanjorski, D-Pa. His assessment? ``It might be exciting for a month; after that, tiring. ... It's a hard job to be in Congress,'' Milewski said. The philosophy instructor is trying to write a article about the average day in the life of a lawmaker. His conclusion is that their isn't any. Other surprises include: _The close relationship between a lawmaker and his constituents. Luczka said he watched the politician and the people interact at a town meeting in Bucks County, Pa., when he visited with Rep. Peter Kostmayer, D-Pa. Milewski said he was surprised that people call their representatives by their first name. _The powerful role of the press. The Poles say there is too much theater and not enough attention to issues, with politicians playing to the television cameras and courting news coverage. The other side of the coin is irresponsible reporting, they say. ``Reporters need to be more careful about the facts,'' Milewski said. _The advances of technology. The interns are agog at such technological innovations that make it possible to print the entire proceedings of Congress the next day in the Congressional Record. In Poland, computers, copiers and facsimile machines are few and far between, the interns said. In fact, a 12-member delegation headed by the Joseph Stewart, the secretary of the Senate, recently visited Poland to assess the technical needs of that country's Parliament. The plan is for Congress to come up with equipment for the Poles. Catherine Messina of the National Forum Foundation, a group that raised private money to pay for the East European interns, said the feedback on the program has been ``overwhelmingly positive.''

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Jolts Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook north and eastern Taiwan early Monday. There were no immediate reports of major damage or casualties, police said. The Central Weather Bureau said the quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale. The epicenter was off the coast about 33 miles northeast of the Taiwanese town of Hualien. The tremor was felt in the capital of Taipei, 112 miles northwest of Hualian, the bureau said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a 10-fold increase in intensity. An quake with a magnitude of 6 is capable of causing widespread damage.

DOC.TEXT: Greta Garbo, the legendary screen star who turned her back on Hollywood in 1941 and became as well known for her passion for privacy as for her sculpted beauty and husky vibrato, died Sunday. She was 84. ``New York Hospital announces with great sadness the death of Miss Garbo,'' said hospital spokesman Andrew Banoff. At the family's request, he provided no other information other than that she died Sunday. He declined to say when she entered the hospital or at what time she died. Ben Buttenweiser, a neighbor and friend of Miss Garbo, said the actress hadn't been well lately and had had dialysis treatments, but didn't know the nature of her illness. Banoff declined to say whether Miss Garbo had been treated for kidney trouble. The Swedish-born star began her career in silent films and reigned as the supreme movie queen throughout the '30s. Some critics considered her the finest screen actress of all time. Actor Jimmy Stewart recalled Sunday night that Miss Garbo had a certain mystique about her. ``It was a combination of the way she looked, her voice and the beautiful way she moved,'' Stewart said. ``As an actress and as a person she had this very special thing about her that I think sort of set her apart ...'' He said he never really got to know Miss Garbo, but was always a fan. ``I think her mystique was her privacy,'' said comedian Milton Berle. ``She was a wonderful actress and she was very glamorous.'' Berle said that during his days in vaudeville, he wore clothes like Miss Garbo's on stage. After her retirement at age 36, Miss Garbo never acted again, but her luminous performances in 24 films kept her name alive and made her a favorite of younger generations who saw in her an ethereal ideal of the ultimate woman. While ``Camille,'' and ``Ninotchka'' became film festival staples, the woman known worldwide simply as ``Garbo'' remained shuttered in her Manhattan apartment or at various retreats in France and Switzerland. She suffered little illness through most of her life, and was a health enthusiast who enjoyed long walks. Carl Peterson, a doorman and elevator operator at her Manhattan apartment building, said she didn't look well when he last saw her early last week. ``She had gray hair and was very thin,'' Peterson said. ``She looked very pathetic.'' When Miss Garbo traveled it was with the air of a phantom, slipping in and out of airports, wearing dark glasses and a slouch hat pulled down. She was usually only a few steps ahead of persistent photographers who stalked her incessantly and occasionally managed to steal a quick shot of ``The Face.'' Her most-remembered line was in ``Grand Hotel'' when she said, ``I want to be alone.'' She was also reputed to have said the same to reporters, although she once insisted to a friend that what she had said was, `I want to be let alone.'' In comments published in Life magazine in 1989, Garbo described herself as a ``sour little creature.'' ``I don't want any kind of attention from anybody, except that I know that someone likes me, and that's nice. Otherwise, it's sickening,'' she said. Rumors of love affairs were plentiful but she never married and in her later years allowed only a few long-time friends to penetrate her solitude.Few would discuss the star, knowing they would lose her friendship if they did. But those who did comment indicated they had never been allowed to know her secrets. She was born Greta Lovisa Gustaffson in Stockholm on Sept. 18, 1905, the daughter of an uneducated laborer who was often ill or unemployed. After her father died when she was 14, she left school to become a barber's helper and later a $25-a-month department store clerk. While clerking in the hat department, she was chosen to appear in a filmed hat advertisement. Stagestruck, the 17-year-old Greta enrolled in Stockholm's Royal Dramatic Theater Academy and haunted film studios seeking work. She won several bit parts, the first in a 1923 comedy titled ``Peter the Tramp.'' But her big break came when Mauritz Stiller, then Sweden's leading director, visited the Academy and discovered the tall, angular beauty. He made her his protege, changed her name to Garbo and starred her in his 1924 silent movie, ``The Atonement of Gosta Berling.'' The film depicted her wrapped in furs and huddled in a horse-drawn sled as it sped away from a pack of pursuing wolves. At the first sight of Miss Garbo on film, Stiller said, ``Her face. You only get a face like that in front of a camera once in a century.'' Stiller's film caught the attention of Hollywood movie tycoon Louis B. Mayer, who offered the director a contract at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios. Stiller agreed on the condition that Miss Garbo be signed, too. She stepped onto American soil in 1925, and from her first American appearance in the silent film, ``The Torrent,'' Miss Garbo captivated audiences. Her career soared with such silent films as ``Flesh and the Devil,'' ``The Divine Woman,'' and ``Woman of Affairs'' but when talkies began studio officials feared her voice might not please audiences. They were wrong. Talking pictures revealed her throaty, sensual voice and further enhanced her appeal. She became an international sensation, drawing rave reviews in ``Mata Hari,'' ``Grand Hotel,'' ``Queen Christina'' and many more. Many film buffs can recite her first spoken line, to a bartender at a waterfront saloon in ``Anna Christie'': ``Gimme a viskey _ ginger ale on the side _ and don't be stingy, baby.'' Response to the sight of her chisled features and lithe body sometimes was so frenzied that the phenomenon became known as ``Garbomania.'' By the 1930s, she was reportedly earning between $250,000 to $300,000 a picture. Her leading men included some of the greatest stars of the time _ Clark Gable in ``Susan Lennox,'' John Barrymore in ``Grand Hotel,'' Fredric March in ``Anna Karenina,'' Robert Taylor in ``Camille,'' and Charles Boyer in ``Conquest.''

DOC.TEXT: At various times she was reported to be ready to marry actor John Gilbert, maestro Leopold Stokowski, health food enthusiast Gayelord Hauser and director Rouben Mamoulian. But as she had said early in her career, ``Marriage? I have said over and over again that I do not know.'' Her career began to wane in the late 1930s but bounced back with the comedy ``Ninotchka,'' which prompted marquees across America to blaze ``Garbo Laughs!'' But her next attempt at a humorous role in ``Two-faced Woman'' flopped and Miss Garbo announced her retirement in 1941. In 1949, she went to Italy to film ``La Duchesse de Langlais,'' but the project was delayed and eventually fell through. Miss Garbo, a millionaire through many investments, had no need to work again. She never did. Although nominated four times for Academy Awards, she didn't win one until 1955 _ a special Oscar for ``a series of luminous and unforgettable performances.'' She did not appear to collect it. She became an American citizen in 1951 and moved her permanent home from Hollywood to Manhattan, where she sometimes used the name Harriet Brown. She also maintained a residence in Klosters, Switzerland. ``Garbo watchers'' would wait hours outside her apartment, hoping to catch a glimpse of her. Details of her private life rarely leaked out, but in the 1940s she was linked with Russian-born entrepreneur George Schlee, whose wife, Valentina, designed Miss Garbo's clothes. She purchased an apartment in the Schlees' building; the entrepreneur was soon traveling alone with Miss Garbo, although he remained married. The relationship lasted nearly 25 years until Schlee died in 1964. Her enduring popularity was evident when in the 1960s dozens of ``Garbo Festivals'' were held worldwide. But Miss Garbo, as always, remained aloof. In a rare interview, in 1928, she said, ``There are many things in your heart you can never tell to another person. They are you, your private joys and sorrows, and you can never tell them. You cheapen yourself, the inside of yourself, when you tell them.'' When she saw the words in print, Miss Garbo was furious with the writer. ``I do not like your story,'' she said. However, in 1985, Sven Broman, a Swedish magazine publisher and Garbo biographer, released details of conversations he said he had had the summer before with the actress. According to Broman, Miss Garbo said she longed to return to Sweden, but feared the resulting commotion. Neighbor Buttenweiser said he had known the actress for 35 years. He said he sometimes discussed world developments with Garbo, but said she wouldn't talk about her film career. ``She wanted to know about Germany, about Europe. She wanted to know what was going on in New York,'' said Buttenweiser. ``She was a very interesting person.'' For most of her life, the actress apparently decided to let her films speak for her. ``The result of our life should bear witness to what we are, what we will do, what we can achieve,'' she said as a budding teen-age star. ``And our work tells this best in its own language. Mine happens to be the language of the motion picture screen.'' New York Hospital spokesman Banoff said the family had asked that, instead of flowers, donations be made to a kidney treatment center at the hospital. He said he didn't know who the family members were, but neighbors said Miss Garbo had a niece. He said services would be private.

DOC.HEAD: Marchers Protest Police Killings in Houston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Sunday demonstration; picks up 6th graf, `Former Officer ...' Ester in 3rd graf cq
DOC.TEXT: About 50 people planted a black cross Sunday near the spot where one of two blacks were killed last fall by police officers, including one who faces a murder trial Monday. More than 200 people marched through downtown Saturday to protest the killings. During the two-block procession, children carried placards shaped like tombstones, which bore the names of people killed by officers. ``We're here today to say that these young black children do not have targets painted on their backs,'' said Ester King, a member of the National Black United Front. The march was organized by the Ida Lee Delaney-Byron Gillum Justice Committee. Ms. Delaney, 50, and Gillum, 24, both black, were fatally shot within two weeks of each other last fall by city police officers. On Sunday, about 50 members of the committee planted a black cross in cement near the University of Houston campus where Gillum was killed. Former Officer Alex Gonzales, 25, goes on trial Monday in Dallas for Ms. Delaney's death. The case was moved because of extensive publicity in Houston. Ms. Delaney was heading to work on a freeway when Gonzales and two other off-duty officers in an unmarked car chased her pickup truck for several miles after she had cut in front of them. After Ms. Delaney pulled over, she opened fire and exchanged shots with Gonzales, investigators said. Authorities said Gonzales and his companions were not in uniforms and had been at a nightclub for several hours before the Oct. 31 shooting. Hospital records showed Gonzales was drunk when he sought treatment for gunshot wounds to the abdomen, authorities said. All three officers were fired, but only Gonzales was indicted, on a first-degree murder charge. All are appealing their firings to independent arbitrators. If convicted, Gonzales could be sentenced to 99 years in prison. Earlier this month, grand jurors declined to indict former Officer Scott Tschirhart, 27, for the Nov. 15 slaying of Gillum, an off-duty security guard. Tschirhart, who is white, fired eight shots at Gillum _ four in the back _ after Gillum reached for a gun during a traffic stop, according to the officer. Gillum was the third black killed by Tschirhart during his seven years on the force. He was dismissed after an internal investigation of the Gillum case. Grand juries declined to indict the officer after the 1985 shooting death of a man who had tried to stop Tschirhart from arresting a woman, and after the 1983 shooting death of a suspected car thief who had rammed the officer's patrol car and started shooting. During Saturday's rally, marchers chanted, ``Justice for Ida, Byron too. The next one they shoot might be you.'' And later, ``HPD, have you heard? This is no Johannesburg.'' The marchers were demanding a civilian review board of abuse by police, the appointment of a special prosecutor and a new grand jury investigation of Tschirhart. Marchers vowed to carry their protests to Dallas on Monday. ``This is not a threat. This is a warning. We need justice,'' said Robert Mohammed, who heads the Houston mosque of the Nation of Islam.

DOC.HEAD: 30,000 Remember Britain's Worst Sports Disaster
DOC.TEXT: About 15,000 of England's noisiest soccer fans were silent Sunday, honoring 95 people who died a year ago at the Hillsborough stadium in Britain's worst sports tragedy. Liverpool's Anfield stadium _ about 60 miles north of the neutral Hillsborough stadium _ was transformed from a soccer field into a makeshift church as fans, Liverpool players and relatives of the dead attended a memorial service. Most of those killed were Liverpool supporters. Loud, match-day chanting was replaced by prayers and quiet thoughts of the those who died at Hillsborough in the Football Association Cup semifinal game between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest, a match that should have been one of the highlights of the season. And at 3:06 p.m., the 15,000 fell silence for a minute to remember those who were crushed or suffocated when police opened a stadium gate to alleviate crowding outside the stadium. As the crowd rushed into the already filled terrace, or standing-room section, many were crushed against anti-riot fences and barriers circling the field. The tragedy has led to plans to improve crowd control at English soccer grounds, including the compulsory switch to all-seat stadiums. But those measures were a long way from the thoughts of the supporters and their families at Anfield Sunday. ``Liverpool, its city and its football clubs, are renowned for their family spirit,'' Liverpool's Roman Catholic archbishop, Derek Worlock, said. ``So we were all filled with horror and distress at what happened that Saturday afternoon.''

DOC.HEAD: Greta Garbo
DOC.TEXT: Greta Garbo, the legendary screen star who turned her back on Hollywood in 1941 and became as well known for her passion for privacy as for her sculpted beauty and husky vibrato, died Sunday. She was 84. The Swedish-born star began her career in silent films and reigned as the supreme movie queen throughout the '30s. Some critics considered her the finest screen actress of all time. Actor Jimmy Stewart recalled that Miss Garbo had a certain mystique about her. ``It was a combination of the way she looked, her voice and the beautiful way she moved,'' Stewart said. ``As an actress and as a person she had this very special thing about her that I think sort of set her apart.'' After her retirement at age 36, Miss Garbo never acted again, but her luminous performances in 24 films kept her name alive and made her a favorite of younger generations who saw in her an ethereal ideal of the ultimate woman. While ``Camille,'' and ``Ninotchka'' became film festival staples, the woman known worldwide simply as ``Garbo'' remained shuttered in her Manhattan apartment or at various retreats in France and Switzerland. Her most-remembered line was in ``Grand Hotel'' when she said, ``I want to be alone.'' She was also reputed to have said the same to reporters, although she once insisted to a friend that what she had said was, `I want to be let alone.''
DOC.HEAD: Spark Matsunaga
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Spark M. Matsunaga of Hawaii, a longtime advocate for peace and champion of Japanese-Americans seeking compensation for their internment during World War II, died of cancer early Sunday in Toronto. He was 73. Matsunaga, a Japanese-American who was highly decorated in World War II, was first elected to the House in 1962 and the Senate in 1976. He was known more for his easygoing manner and his warm treatment of constituents than his impact on legislation. But when he cared deeply about an issue, he combined skill and perseverance to win passage. In 1988 Matsunaga engineered passage of a $1.25 billion law that pays $20,000 to each surviving Japanese-American interned in a U.S. prison camp during World War II. After graduating from the University of Hawaii with honors in 1941, Matsunaga joined the 100th Infantry Battalion, which later became part of the famed 442nd Regimental Combat Team. The ``Go for Broke'' 442nd would become the most decorated regiment in U.S. history. Matsunaga was wounded twice during World War II. He was awarded numerous medals, including the Bronze Star and Purple Heart with cluster.
DOC.HEAD: Marcos Robles
DOC.TEXT: Marcos Aurelio Robles, a former president of Panama who oversaw the construction of a part of the Pan-American Highway, died after a long illness Saturday in Miami, family members said Sunday. He was 84. Robles was elected president in 1964. He was succeeded in 1968 by Arnulfo Arias, the last elected president of Panama before a military coup Oct. 11 that year led by Gen. Omar Torrijos. Robles fled to Miami after the military overthrow. Robles was born Nov. 8, 1905, in the western town of Aguadulce. A member of the Liberal Party, served as a congressman, minister of justice, treasury minister and an executive with the National Bank of Panama. He created the Institute for Human Resources and oversaw the construction of part of the Pan-American Highway, which connects Panama to the United States.
DOC.HEAD: John Bruce-Gardyne
DOC.TEXT: Baron John Bruce-Gardyne, a former treasury official in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's first administration, died Sunday after a long illness, the prime minister's office said. He was 60. The cause of death was not announced, but he underwent surgery for a brain tumor last year. Bruce-Gardyne, known as Jock, was a fierce advocate of monetarist policies and served as treasury minister for 21 months for Mrs. Thatcher. He served as minister of state in 1981 and economic secretary from 1981-83. ``He was a marvelous colleague, loyal, but always retaining an independent mind,'' Mrs. Thatcher said Sunday. Bruce-Gardyne worked as Paris correspondent for the Financial Times before going into politics. He was elected as a Conservative member of Parliament from 1964 to 1974, and again from 1979 to 1983, when boundary changes dissolved his district. After failing to win nomination for the next election, he retired from Parliament and was created a life peer.
DOC.HEAD: Thurston Harris
DOC.TEXT: Thurston Harris, whose songs ``Over and Over'' and ``Little Bitty Pretty One'' were smash hits in the 1950s, died of a heart attack at a rest home Saturday. He was 58. Harris achieved fame that quickly faded to obscurity, but he never gave up hope of a comeback, said relatives and his agent. He was preparing to sue to obtain the rights to some of his recordings and had a contract for an October concert at the Greek Theater in Los Angeles, said Steve Brigati, Harris' manager and agent for the past three years. ``He was singing `Over and Over' all evening long,'' in preparation for the concert, said Rosemary Mingo, a resident at Cook's Care Facility here. Harris never got any royalties for his songs, said his daughter, Jewel Rene Harris.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Charged With Murder in Hospital Shootings That Killed Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Also killed ...', with 1 graf to UPDATE with trainee's name; picks up 8th graf, `Dr. Michael ...' SUBS grafs 11-12, bgng `The elder ...', with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details on suspect's behavior Saturday morning; picks up 13th graf, `Police said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A man was being held Sunday in the shooting deaths of two people during a rampage in a hospital emergency room where his father had died hours earlier, authorities said. Bradford Warren Powers Jr., 46, was being held for investigation of murder and investigation of attempted murder, said San Diego police agent J.C. Webber. He surrendered shortly after the shooting spree Saturday evening at Mission Bay Memorial Hospital, Webber said. Webber said the shootings apparently were sparked by the death of Powers' father, who died at the hospital Saturday morning. Deborah Burke, who had worked as a nurse at the hospital for about five years, died during surgery at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, said Dr. Brent Eastman, director of trauma services. Ms. Burke died of a single gunshot wound to the chest, Eastman said. A Mission Bay emergency room trainee, Edward Thomas Rooney, 30, died at the scene from multiple gunshot wounds, Deputy Coroner Dan Matticks said. Dr. Michael Hughes, an emergency room physician, suffered a superficial gunshot wound to the abdomen and a gunshot wound to his right hip, and was in good condition Sunday, Eastman said. Frederick Mowrer, 38, the father of a patient who was being treated in the emergency room, was treated at Mission Bay for a superficial gunshot wound to the buttocks and released Saturday. Mowrer, a New Mexico attorney, and his wife had taken their 2-year-old daughter to the emergency room with flu symptoms. Powers was in the emergency room Saturday morning with his father, Bradford Warren Powers Sr., who died about 5 a.m., said Jeffrey Simmons, a Mission Bay Hospital spokesman. The younger Powers had argued with hospital staffers Saturday morning, but had not threatened violence, said Dr. Harry Henderson, hospital chief of staff-elect. ``He was certainly concerned that his father had died and was perhaps concerned that he did not receive proper care,'' Henderson said. ``We didn't think it was going to be anything out of the ordinary.'' The elder Powers had suffered an abdominal aneurysm and required emergency surgery, Henderson said Sunday. But the younger Powers had told doctors not to operate, saying the 75-year-old man would not be able to survive the surgery because of his age and his medical condition, Henderson said. Henderson said the man would have died without the operation. He said the surgery was successful but the man died of cardiac arrest on the operating table. Police said Powers returned to the emergency room about 12 hours after his father's death and began randomly firing a handgun. Police Sgt. Ernest Ullrey of Oceanside, about 40 miles north of the hospital, said Powers called the department from a pay phone about 6 p.m., saying he wanted to confess. Officers arrested Powers at the phone booth, Ullrey said.

DOC.HEAD: Wellesley Students Oppose Barbara Bush Scheduled Commencement Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Nanerl Keohane' in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The selection of first lady Barbara Bush as the commencement speaker at Wellesley College is being protested by students who say she doesn't ``embody the Wellesley experience.'' Mrs. Bush is scheduled to speak at graduation ceremonies June 1 at the all-woman school in this Boston suburb. ``To honor Barbara Bush as a commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley,'' said a petition signed by 150 students. The petition was recently presented to college President Nanerl Keohane. Senior Susie Cardenas, who helped organize the petition drive, said Mrs. Bush is ``not representative and does not embody the Wellesley experience _ what we're trying to go after in life. Wellesley spokeswoman Laura Stavis defended the invitation. ``The point of fact is (Mrs. Bush holds) a very important position,'' Stavis said. ``She is and continues to be involved in crucial issues, literacy, volunteer programs for the needy and the homeless. I feel she speaks with her own voice.'' Anna Perez, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bush's office in Washington, said Sunday she would have no comment on the students' petition. Not all students agreed with the protest. ``I think it's fabulous we can get someone that prestigious to speak,'' said junior Carrie Workman. ``I don't think you can write her off as just marrying a famous man.'' Other students expressed concern about the presence of security and Secret Service agents on campus on graduation day. ``It's a private day,'' said senior Helen Yannatos. ``It's what we worked for years for. It will take away from it in a sense.''

In an Easter Sunday salute to man's yearning for freedom, Pope John Paul II said he hoped Lithuanians would achieve their goal of independence through ``respectful and comprehensive'' dialog with Moscow. In other Easter celebrations, Romanians and East Germans gave thanks for the freedoms won by their pro-democracy revolutions, and religious leaders called for peace and tolerance in Lebanon and Israel. The pontiff spoke as Lithuanians waited to see whether Soviet President Mikihail S. Gorbachev would carry out his threat to impose economic sanctions on the republic unless it rescinded independence-oriented actions by Sunday. ``In the name of Jesus dead and risen for all men, we ask for peace for our children in the dear Lithuania nation, while we hope that their aspirations find confirmation in a respectful and comprehensive dialogue,'' the pope said.

You won't be through with taxes for the year even if you beat the midnight Monday deadline for filing your federal return. The average American will have to work through May 5 to satisfy the tax collectors. If that prediction by the Tax Foundation proves accurate, it will be the latest ``Tax Freedom Day'' on record and two days later than 1989. The reason is simple, the nonpartisan research organization said Sunday in announcing the mythical date: ``Tax increases will outpace the growth in individuals' income during 1990.'' Tax Freedom Day is the foundation's estimate of how long it would take an average person to pay his or her state, federal and local taxes if all income went for taxes until they were all paid for the year 1990.

Chinatown, normally jammed with tourists, has been suffering financially since October's earthquake smashed one of the main highways leading to the maze of crowded streets and bustling shops. So when Mayor Art Agnos suggested the crippled Embarcadero Freeway be destroyed instead of repaired, with a new road built at ground level or underground, merchants decided they had had enough. Activist Rose Pak of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce is leading the fight to rebuild the 1.7-mile freeway. At her urging, hundreds of Chinatown merchants planned to lock their doors Monday and show up at a Board of Supervisors meeting where the freeway's fate was expected to be decided. Agnos argues the freeway is ugly _ it blocks prime views of San Francisco Bay _ and too expensive to repair and reopen.

The boos drowned out Dianne Feinstein when she told California Democrats, ``Yes, I support the death penalty.'' But the former San Francisco mayor was betting that her stand would draw cheers from voters worried about drugs and crime. Her judgment is echoed in campaigns from California to the Eastern seaboard, from the Sun Belt to the Rust Belt. It is an election year in which death and politics are locked in a rhetorical embrace and candidates engage in macabre numbers games. In a campaign ad, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida proclaims he has signed ``some 90 death warrants.'' But only five people have been executed since Martinez took office in 1987. ``As district attorney and attorney general he's put or kept 277 murderers on death row,'' said an ad for John Van de Kamp, who says he personally opposes capital punishment. Nobody's been executed in 23 years in California, where Van de Kamp and Feinstein are battling for the Democratic nomination for governor.

The amorous escapades of a 10,000-pound Asian elephant named Indy have captured the attention of the zoo world. The 18-year-old pachyderm has impregnated two females at the Burnett Park Zoo. Babe is expected to deliver her baby around the last week of April and Romani is due in July 1991. That's earth-shaking news for the continent's zoos, where just 62 calves have ever been born in captivity. It's also a sign of promise for the 35,000 to 45,000 Asian elephants that remain in the wild as an endangered species. ``North American zoos are getting serious about reproducing elephants. The two pregnancies at Syracuse is evidence we are making progress,'' said Tom Foose, conservation director for the American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums.

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Guidelines for Environmental Behavior
With AM-Social Resolutions
DOC.TEXT: The ``Valdez Principles,'' 10 rules for corporate conduct regarding the environment, have become a focal point of the shareholder activist movement this year. They were composed by the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies, a consortium of environmental organizations and social investors that include the Sierra Club, National Audobon Society, National Wildlife Federation and the controllers of New York City, New York State and California, who manage large pension funds that invest in stocks of many companies. Although the principles are named after the Exxon oil spill that fouled Valdez, Alaska, in March 1989, the CERES group says it began formulating them well before then. They were released last September. So far no company has pledged to become a signatory to the principles, but many have expressed interest and some have promised to provide progress reports on how they plan to adhere to them. The CERES group intends to release a corporate guide for how to become a signatory later this month. Here are the principles as provided by CERES: 1. Protection of the Biosphere: Minimize and seek to eliminate the release of pollutants that cause damage to the air, water, or earth or its inhabitants. Safeguard habitats in rivers, lakes, wetlands, coastal zones and oceans and minimize contributing to the greenhouse effect, depletion of the ozone layer, acid rain or smog. 2. Sustainable use of natural resources: Make sustainable use of renewable resources, such as water, soils, and forests. Conserve nonrenewable natural resources through efficient use and careful planning. Protect wildlife habitat, open spaces and wilderness, while preserving biodiversity. 3. Reduction and Disposal of Wastes: Minimize the creation of waste, especially hazardous waste, and wherever possible recycle materials. Dispose of waste through safe and responsible methods. 4. Wise Use of Energy: Make every effort to use environmentally safe and sustainable energy sources to meet our needs. Invest in improved energy efficiency and conservation in our operations. Maximize energy efficiency of products we produce or sell. 5. Risk Reduction: Minimize environmental, health and safety risks to employees and communities in which we operate by employing safe technologies and operating procedures and by being constantly prepared for emergencies. 6. Marketing of Safe Products and Services: Sell products or services that minimize environmental impacts and are safe as consumers use them. Inform consumers of environmental impacts of products or services. 7. Damage Compensation: Take responsibility for harm we cause to the environment by making every effort to fully restore the environment and to compensate persons adversely affected. 8. Disclosure: Disclose to employees and to the public incidents relating to operations that cause environmental harm or pose health and safety hazards. Disclose potential environmental, health or safety hazards posed by operations and take no action against employees who report conditions that create a danger to the environment or pose health and safety hazards. 9. Environmental Directors and Managers: Have a person qualified to represent environmental interests on the board. Commit management resources to implement these Principles, including funding an office of vice president for environmental affairs or an equivalent executive position, reporting directly to the CEO, to monitor and report upon implementation efforts. 10. Assessment and Annual Audit: Conduct and make public an annual self-evaluation of progress in implementing these Principles and in complying with all applicable laws and regulations throughout worldwide operations. Work toward timely creation of independent environmental audit procedures completed annually and made available to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Doubled IRA Contributions to $31.5 Billion, Money Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans will have put $31.5 billion into Individual Retirement Accounts by Monday's 1989 tax filing deadline, Money magazine reported. The latest year's total is more than double the $15 billion added to IRAs in 1988 but lags well behind the record $50 billion invested in 1986, the year before Congress reduced the deductibility of contributions, the magazine said. The total amount held in IRAs rose $72 billion in the last year to $465 billion, Money said. Earnings from existing investments accounted for $40.5 billion of the increase. Of the $31.5 billion of new money put into retirement accounts, the magazine said investors put $17.5 billion into mutual funds. Such funds now are the most popular form of investment, accounting for 24 percent of all IRA funds.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Killed In Tank Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A Citgo Petroleum Corp. worker was killed Sunday morning in an explosion in a tank field at Port of Tampa, authorities said. The worker died when a vapor recovery unit exploded, igniting a fire that scorched tanks full of gasoline before it was brought under control. Fire boats, helicopters and ground personnel sprayed foam on the tanks to keep them from catching fire, said Tampa Fire Department spokesman Matt Ballaban. ``It did threaten them for a time, but we were able to extinguish it with foam,'' Ballaban said. The fire sent thick black smoke billowing across Tampa. Ballaban said 16 fire units and some 50 firefighters brought the blaze under control in less than an hour. There were no other injuries reported. The employee's name was being withheld pending notification of relatives, said Citgo spokesman Kent Young in Tulsa, Okla. ``Terminal operations are being suspended,'' Young said. ``An investigation is under way to determine the cause of the explosion.'' Citgo's Tampa operation has capacity to hold 241,000 barrels of oil.

DOC.HEAD: US West Files First Stock Offering to Raise $525 Million
DOC.TEXT: U S West Inc. has filed plans to make its first stock offering in its six-year history to raise about $525 million for several projects, company officials said. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday, U S West disclosed plans to offer 14 million new shares of common stock. The stock fell 25 cents Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange to $74.75. The new shares will be offered after a 2-for-1 stock split, which the company announced on April 6. The split and the stock offering are designed to raise interest in the company among small investors, a company spokesman said. Money raised by the sale will help fund several pending projects including expansion of core-phone service in the company's 14-state service region, U S West said. The money also will help the company expand its financial services arm and finance cable television projects in Hong Kong and Great Britain, it said. The offering will bring the total number of outstanding US West shares to 389.1 million. Englewood-based U S West was one of the seven Baby Bell companies formed by the breakup of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. in 1984. The company's stock performance has been lower than the six other Baby Bells. Its stock rose about 149 percent from 1984 through last month, compared with about 176 percent for the group as a whole.

DOC.HEAD: China Lower Deposit Rates in Effort to Boost Economy
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on bank deposits were reduced by 1.26 percentage points in a move aimed at stimulating China's sluggish economy. The People's Bank of China said Sunday the new rates would apply to deposits by individuals, enterprises and institutions, the official press reported. It follows a decision by the central bank to lower interest rates on business loans, also by 1.26 percentage points, on March 21. The interest rate on a one-year deposit will fall to 10.08 percent from 11.34 percent, while the rate for a three-year deposit will drop to 11.88 percent from 13.14 percent. Lower deposit rates could encourage people to put less of their income into savings and spend more, giving the economy a needed boost. Tough austerity measures imposed in late 1988 have succeeded in reducing inflation from a high of more than 30 percent to about 4 percent in February, but at the cost of a sharp economic slowdown that has chilled consumer demand and led to thousands of plant closures. In recent months the government, concerned about economic recession, has begun easing its tight credit policies and increasing the money supply to bail out debt-ridden companies. People's Bank Governor Li Guixian said the reduction of interest rates on loans in March would cut enterprise debt burdens by 17 billion yuan a year, or the equivalent of $3.6 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Sudan Disagrees With IMF Proposals
DOC.TEXT: A senior official said Sudan does not intend to accept the economic reform program proposed by the International Monetary Fund, which includes a sharp devaluation of the country's currency. Col. Salah el-Din Karrar, a member of the ruling 15-man military council, was quoted by al-Sudan al-Hadith newspaper as saying the government will accept only its own economic reform program. ``We will not back out on our economic program whether there is agreement or disagreement with the IMF,'' he said. The IMF declared Sudan ineligible for loans in 1986. The military government, which came to power June 30, has held two inconclusive rounds of talks with the international agency. The next round of talks start May 5. Karrar gave no details of the government's program except to say it was a counterproposal to an IMF proposal. He said a recent IMF proposal to devalue the Sudanese pound was unacceptable. The IMF proposed that the official exchange rate be devalued to 15 pounds to the dollar from 4.5 pounds currently, and the tourist rate be changed to 30 pounds to the dollar from 12.10 pounds, Karrar said. The Sudanese government is burdened by a $13 billion foreign debt. The 7-year-old civil war in the south costs the government $1 million a day.
